title: Developmental Domain 1: Social and Emotional Development
subject: Early Learning Guidelines: Birth to Age 3 (2012-)

document.title: Illinois Early Learning Guidelines For Children Birth to Age Three

E27E4D190589421F8F479350D6C1DBD4.description:
Shares in and shows an emotional response for peers’ feelings,
e.g., may show concern for a child who is hurt, or smile for a
child who is happy and jumping up and down

93CD2C92C6DA4633BC82916C01B3ACD8.description:
Responds to a child in distress in an attempted manner to make
that child feel better, e.g., gives a crying child a hug, uses soothing words, or uses distraction

B20FC26FDF1546D589D6E3F294BE2AA7.description:
Communicates how other children may be feeling and why, e.g.,
states that a peer is sad because his or her toy was taken away

7967AFB4A7FE44FCBB509C785C26F08F.description:
Shares in and communicates simple emotions of others, e.g.,
“mama sad”, “papa happy”

5DC978BA38514430904868DC669A45C7.description:
Demonstrates awareness of different emotions and feelings
during play, e.g., rocks a baby doll and whispers “shhh”

DC75E43D6A5C40B3948C7005C071B589.description: Recognizes some of his or her own emotions, e.g., grabs a comfort object when sad

9D2A96D9610A4913B357032603453495.description:
Imitates comforting behaviors from caregiver(s), e.g., pats or
hugs a child when upset

46B4727748CD4B079D7166ED24C2FE0A.description:
Begins to have a greater awareness of own emotions, e.g., says
or gestures “no” to refuse, squeals and continues to laugh when
happy

07610405874F450DB3F18E756C9BC8DB.description:
Shares in both positive and negative emotions with caregiver(s),
e.g., shares in wonders, amazement, delight, and disappointment

41A753489F3C4368A850BABFAA01BDEA.description:
Reacts to a child who is upset by observing or moving physically
closer to the child

818D45346255496B8A1A8F07CC0D77BC.description:
Uses social referencing with caregiver(s) when in uncertain
situations, e.g., glances at a caregiver’s face for cues on how to
respond to an unfamiliar person or new situation

B5734598290D4C028BB8FBCB9BA189FC.description: Smiles with intention to draw out a smile from a familiar other

8E5E10A215DE4BE7BBDE1FE52288E2EE.description:
Begins to share in simple emotions by reading facial and gestural
cues, e.g., repeats activities that make others laugh

0B49577FD117411590844E7B13308749.description: Shows signs of separation anxiety, e.g., protests when a caregiver leaves the room

D8A6E76AD8E24CA3A0B1EC0AAE66F4DD.description:
Responds to interactions from caregiver(s), e.g., smiles when
caregiver smiles, looks toward a caregiver when he or she
shakes a rattle

C20A71CA4E9B4AA5BC824C055D57E0D5.description: Cries when hearing another infant cry

2D455A1F1B4247A1AB62AE37534AC78B.description: Watches and observes adults and other children

A1CEF689A05143B5829CBBC100F5DD8B.description:
Children demonstrate an emerging ability to understand someone else’s feelings and to share in the emotional
experiences of others.

2FF66722BF534F25B89C1F320A918D0F.description: Begins to engage in more complex play with two or three children

770F01B8305C4637969EA20742424127.description:
Communicates with other children in different settings, e.g.,
talks to a peer during snack time, or hands a peer a book

BCD861F874E6466599CAF9626EC30AD2.description:
Becomes frustrated with peers, e.g., yells “no” if a peer tries to
interfere in something he or she is engaged in

A2F6CE0BC2984AE39535C0BF3115C880.description: Demonstrates a preference toward select peers

F6712BC4082C4041886B01AAC3088F41.description:
Demonstrates a preference for parallel play, e.g., plays next to
other children with similar toys with little or no interaction

D29B037E9B3E4956BB3AF8D8D3D12B1E.description:
Begins to engage in simple reciprocal interactions, e.g., rolls a
ball back and forth

FFAFE232580743FCA7E9159163BD498E.description:
Expresses frustration when another child takes something away
from him or her, e.g., a toy

A1F8FF0ECD4141ED8EC4A28E31913AEB.description: Gestures in order to communicate a desire to play near a peer

81F3DE783BD74646899E75709FBBE2AF.description:
Begins to engage in parallel play, in closer proximity to other
children but no interaction is attempted

54A98CBD600D4CBB99B93FBF6A9651F9.description: Engages in a simple, reciprocal game such as “pat-a-cake”

92DCE7C18888492E8A53A210250BAAA7.description: Imitates actions of another child, e.g., rolling a car

F7193A28927A4FDAA7FF7D2D5B319B37.description:
Shows interest in another child by moving closer, e.g., rolls,
crawls, or walks toward the child

E090B582DD24446C92F99CBB2BE8C4A4.description: Attempts to imitate actions, e.g., bangs a toy

C4B88E841B674FA38AE69FD34E1217D6.description: Reaches out to touch another child

43AC4854ABE64760AB09BE3F766BE5CC.description: Cries when hearing another child cry

124866BAA915463B8171082019D2C989.description: Shows interest in both familiar and unfamiliar peers

58E2BF1453E7491EB8A0E9D479F296F3.description: Observes other children in the environment

75C84A8B59D44B629A927D3B90B32916.description:
Demonstrates effort to interact and engage, e.g., uses eye
contact, coos, smiles

9925802E34A64DDAB45E4A9985DD0341.description: Children demonstrate the desire and develop the ability to engage and interact with other children.

7E4592026C86483BA514AE562AF3F80B.description:
Begins to understand concept of possession, e.g., “yours,” “hers,”
“his”

456FC49ED37D42D4AF277E86BC973447.description:
Communicates feelings, e.g., may say “I’m sad,” or stomps feet
when mad

36AB1A6C3333459B84E71933E153D066.description: Demonstrates preferences, e.g., “I want the green cup”

6A746A095BD44B31B0953AB7A470DC28.description:
Begins to show an interest in describing physical characteristics,
e.g., “I have blue eyes”

73EF8BC9864541878C60675EDE1E6D7E.description: Incorporates roles of family members in play

A704F3DFB1B0427087B1DFCC5AB338F3.description:
Asks for help from familiar adults but pushes away and refuses
help

AECDAA0BE27D47A7BC7ACB9BE8691FCD.description: Names people in his/her family and shares stories about them

E14E4E18D0AC4F45BEBC77C340A8D087.description:
Asks for help from familiar adults but may begin to attempt to
complete tasks autonomously

E1844CE3C347428084BB6C0CA7B244FB.description: Points to self in images and other types of media

8F76B72068F1453894BF217B8F011CB7.description:
Demonstrates understanding and use of concepts through words
such as “mine,” “me,” and “you”

A338BBB1516749189D663097B6E430B9.description: Refers to self with gestures and language

DEA35FE3157C4008ABD1E734FDA88EF0.description: Able to express his or her name

D580999D4DEE48A1A307D6A3690B462A.description:
Demonstrates awareness of self, e.g., touches own nose in the
mirror

2BF2F8F54F41487EBF7B66149A2188D0.description:
Points to and identifies body parts on him or herself, e.g., points
to eyes when asked, “Where are your eyes?”

D38E6FCFC6F244088BFA7946B50A9D4A.description: Uses social referencing to guide actions and begins to test limits

65D23DE484C242878AA5529260E89333.description: Uses gestures and some words to express feelings, e.g., “no”

BD1EF51A4FE24A3CBC3F9C1599CE67CC.description: Demonstrates interest in looking in mirror

436F0DA8F4D947CB9F381D849D0E4004.description: Responds with vocalizations or gestures when hears name

994C87104F91421B813803CBAEF1D785.description:
Engages in joint attention with familiar others, e.g., shares in
looking and engaging with objects and people

C7E707558E9143DFA50B36F96A82CBDA.description:
Shows awareness of significant people by calling them by name,
e.g., “papa”

D7F3FF4055BF42BFBE38E2CBCC9D8318.description:
Demonstrates separation anxiety, e.g., cries when caregiver
leaves the room

26F6F844E2E747E3B7FF542E6976D7CC.description:
Begins to display the beginning of joint attention, e.g., points to
objects and people

27A1571027D840DAAB207965C9B404AD.description:
Initiates interactions with others, e.g., imitates actions, plays
peek-a-boo

B63E642AAC134C18B955980B6C4A54AC.description:
Recognizes and prefers familiar adults and siblings, e.g., leans
toward caregiver when being held by someone else

78F0541B52ED48E2B75DDE65759D2DC6.description:
Recognizes own name, e.g., looks up, or turns head toward a
person who is saying his/her name

0DC43767D508478DA94F2701FE17CF30.description: Explores his or her own hands and feet

306EC0D9510A476AA9005ED99A206939.description: Demonstrates interest in faces and voices of others

5B06791A7E0946E48CFBAA3CC3C1C3BA.description:
Demonstrates desire to control or make decisions independent
from adults

314A35202EFF462E9B59EB9E7B50799F.description:
Communicates thoughts, feelings, questions, and plans to both
familiar and unfamiliar adults

DB25E08473374620A7C6260E5C6D8461.description:
Initiates activities that are meaningful in the relationship, e.g.,
brings over a favorite book to be read together

85355F5617504441A7324D6C7BAAD410.description:
Imitates adult roles and activities through pretend play, e.g.,
goes grocery shopping, or prepares a meal

0D6400B866944064825432E9AD0AC951.description:
Imitates a familiar adult‘s actions, e.g., waves hands around
while pretending to talk on the phone after seeing caregiver
make those same actions

59E21C426C88449ABDB5C81BABB8D294.description:
Responds to guidance, e.g., places the shape into the shape
sorter after caregiver demonstrates how to

6BD7A3DD8DD14ADA8645AD4E2DDE2515.description:
Seeks adult assistance with challenges but may refuse help and
say “no”

8E7D647E1E454D52BC4217E85E5BEDD2.description: Builds emotional connections with other familiar adults, in addition to primary caregiver(s)

F1E1029A941E42FB8377B934087644EF.description:
Draws a familiar adult into an interaction, e.g., hands a book or
toy to engage in together

47B1E4B4D84341179F84F836D9F900AB.description:
Uses “social referencing” when encountering new experiences,
e.g., glances at a caregiver’s face for cues on how to respond to
an unfamiliar person or unknown object

3B4C3EFCE56E4F9D83F378F224A00301.description: Uses key adults as a “secure base” when exploring the environment

D2C6F895615E405280431D349DD1D33F.description:
Engages with adults during play, e.g., bangs on a toy drum and
repeats action after an adult completes the same action

218AD85C8C3F4299B6237FF259361581.description: Looks for caregiver’s response in uncertain situations

DFC9431605064970BCDF556DEA923682.description:
Begins to engage in simple, back-and-forth interactions with a
familiar adult, e.g., plays “peek-a-boo,” babbles in response to an
adult speaking and repeats this interaction

30AA6000C4F04B8DA1247B78DEE0A500.description:
Demonstrates preference for familiar adults, e.g., reaches hands
out to signal for caregiver(s)

DF8E03E7E4D54A73BAAA21CB1B59C4EC.description:
Engages in social interactions with adults through smiles, coos,
and eye contact

4A90C54C9513470D984AA19BE21C8797.description: Attempts to engage both unfamiliar and familiar adults

B85E4BC57A3445B9B161DEAA93F953B6.description:
Uses signals to communicate needs, e.g., crying, body language,
and facial expressions

0E2916B560D34E8190D8FDFE4835C247.description: Children demonstrate the desire and develop the ability to engage, interact, and build relationships with familiar adults.

10E6FFFA17124F49B6E6A9ED7C583950.description:
Engages in play to express emotion, e.g., draws a picture for a
caregiver because he or she misses them, hides a “monster” in a
box due to a fear

2EB97BCDAE984077940215BCCD12EDCB.description: Begins to express complex emotions such as pride, embarrassment, shame, and guilt

0838034AB8EB4882990B16AF46C52FA2.description:
Acts out different emotions while engaged in pretend play,
e.g., cries when pretending to be sad, jumps up and down for
excitement

1A23C45653F94E1299A5A00DAF827881.description: Attempts to use words to describe feelings and names emotions

C2206FA4D95C486894677A1734066982.description:
Expresses wonder and delight while exploring the environment
and engaging others

78AE3D09E6A748B59424ECBFCE17FAD0.description: Attempts to use a word to describe feelings to a familiar adult

1D9805DA8D624144BFE8241F97A7E84F.description: Expresses pride, e.g., smiles, claps, or says, “I did it” after completing a task

49037A6D677E4A70B34BBE86BEEA2A4C.description:
Demonstrates anger and frustration through a wide range of
physical, vocal, and facial expressions, e.g., temper tantrums

F567C90AEDEE4B1EA3A7F43C5299FC05.description:
Recognizes and expresses emotion toward a familiar person,
e.g., shows emotion by hugging a sibling

DEA4966642464AD8928D60C4BBE2FCEE.description: Shows anger and frustration, e.g., cries when a toy is taken away

04FF50C92547403EAEE155847DBAB982.description:
Expresses fear by crying or turning toward caregiver(s) for
comfort

BB671E31A2CB477B83FAB8B39F095E67.description:
Expresses wants with intentionality, e.g., pushes an unwanted
object out of the way, reaches for a familiar adult when wanting
to be carried

68B00A9D77C740C781D11944A563CE86.description:
Demonstrates discomfort, stress, or unhappiness through body
language and sounds, e.g., arches back, moves head, cries

A1DC3091B0354E199310D3B70E999C8C.description:
Expresses emotions through sounds and gestures, e.g., squeals,
laughs, claps

E037E0F12120447894F8E07FAA72E981.description:
Uses facial expressions and sounds to get needs met, e.g., cries,
smiles, gazes, coos

0901C3A375BC499B8E13DE55C9968DB6.description: Children demonstrate an awareness of and the ability to identify and express emotions.

89E18B60B4F54D8686A98C8F4086D572.description:
Separates with assistance from attachment figure with minimal
anxiety

397284D8B3594710828FB1974C53B7D3.description: Communicates thoughts, feelings, and plans to familiar adults

082A6693ACC84C09922AD5B4EFE2B694.description:
Initiates activities that are meaningful in the relationship, e.g.,
brings over a favorite book to be read together

298DCA835F474236B02C76411403B592.description:
Uses glances and words to stay connected, without having to be
physically near or touching the caregiver

6725C2B1211B458D87227139DB0B6492.description:
Actively seeks emotional responses from caregiver(s) by waving,
hugging, and crying

FBC713ECD03D4E9CAE66C4DCE7A1E96C.description:
Plays physically farther away from primary caregiver with
increasing confidence; moves closer as needed

37E6AD8FA44B4A4BB45925482C307A58.description:
Uses imitation and pretend play to make sense of relationships,
e.g., uses a toy to “brush” hair, or feeds and rocks a doll

42DDF31441E94618A9D70EED3FE6B176.description:
Shows an emotional connection with familiar adults other than
the primary caregiver

225A611EE61C4290832451ED31EF550E.description: Initiates and maintains interactions with caregiver(s)

DBB1488AA0224EFFAB849BAEF0D4B2FA.description:
Seeks comfort from caregiver(s) and/or a familiar object, e.g.,
blanket, stuffed animal

75B222FD02A5433884E2E88AB479B10F.description:
Exhibits stranger anxiety and concern in presence of an
unknown person or a new situation

EBE42C6AC0D2444B9F8EBAA25FA66525.description: Uses key adults as a “secure base” when exploring the environment

7F1DFE2D33694B53B16BB315BB6188B6.description:
Uses social referencing with caregiver(s) when in uncertain situations, e.g., will glance at caregiver’s face for cues on how to respond
to an unfamiliar person or new situation

A106182E98C74DD8A41920F461EC26CA.description:
Attempts to change the situation when separation anxiety occurs,
e.g., follows caregiver(s) when he or she leaves the room

7DD9B2E43535406F969F7DD3B6EF567E.description: Distinguishes between primary caregivers and others

8573FBDA093245E082D5B60C4672562E.description:
Exhibits separation anxiety , e.g., does not want to be held by
another person when being held by primary caregiver

BFD7D65E16F141B9A2BDF012183F5113.description: Imitates familiar adults’ gestures and sounds

08B13CF676D4407A9DA925685FEA845C.description: Seeks comfort from a familiar caregiver

431886A159744BA18A109853EF5D2046.description: Responds to caregiver(s) by smiling and cooing

99D54A1E645B4ED69D8CDCF8543C8EE2.description: Establishes, maintains, and disengages eye contact

C12639CF315B48ED8A09483F464E032C.description:
Children form secure attachment relationships with caregivers who are emotionally available, responsive, and
consistent in meeting their needs.
